results.title: I am Joe's spine
results.brief_description: Uses three-dimensional animation and live sequences to provide an understanding of the complexity of the spine’s construction and an awareness of what can happen when the spine and its surrounding muscles are not given proper care.

results.title: I am
results.creator_credit: Gene Feldman and Wombat Productions, Inc.
results.brief_description: Deals with the quest of a boy, entering adolescence, to discover who he is, what makes a person important, and how one gets to be somebody. Emphasises the importance of introspection, fantasy, and attempts at forming meaningful relationships in the development of the individual identity.

results.title: Understanding ourselves: human heredity
results.brief_description: Illustrates the basic concepts of heredity in an easily understandable context. The mechanism whereby human characteristics are passed from generation to generation is discussed. The function of chromosomes, genes, and DNA in the heredity pattern is explained. Also considers the influence of temperament, behaviour and mutation.

results.title: Howard
results.creator_credit: Don Haldane, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The problems of the teenager caught in the crossfire of adult opinion and youthful enthusiasms. Howard, just out of school, was intending to be a chemist, but wanted first to make a footloose tour of Canada with a school pal during his summer vacation. His wish is strongly resisted by his socially conforming parents. Howard’s resultant confusion, to which the film gives shape, illustrates some of the inner conflicts that arise in teenagers when every fresh impulse is rationalised out of existence.

results.title: How to use the reader's guide to periodical literature (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Nassau Library (New York, N.Y.) and Roger Wade Productions
results.brief_description: Describes the scope, uses and features of this periodicals index, and explains the structure of the headings, arrangement and abbreviations in the entries. Presented in an interesting spy story format.

results.title: How to keep a job
results.brief_description: Discusses the habits and attitudes that make for job success once the job is obtained. A man seeking a new job after being fired at his last job is interviewed by the Personnel director of a company and is told that employers want men who are dependable, willing to work, co-operate, loyal and possess initiative.

results.title: How the whale got his throat
results.creator_credit: Stephen Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: Rudyard Kipling’s whimsical story of how the whale got his sieve-like throat is the subject of this animated film. Long ago, after the whale has eaten all the fish in the sea, he decides to consume a sailor on a raft. Once inside the whale the man jumps about, causing hiccups, until the whale agrees to take him home to get rid of him. As he leaves the whale’s mouth at the trip’s end, the sailor lodges a huge grid, made from his cut-up raft, in the whale’s throat so that until this day the whale can eat only very small fish.

results.title: How the first letter was written
results.creator_credit: Lee Mishkin, Nick Bosustow and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Adapted from Rudyard Kipling’s “Just so stories” this animated film is a mythical story about the world’s first letter written by a cave girl humorously illustrating the advantages of written communication.

results.title: How does it feel?
results.creator_credit: Mick Csaky, Arts Council of Great Britain and Pictures That Move
results.brief_description: Covers various areas of neurophysiology, creativity and bio energetic therapy, with a commentary about getting back in touch with our senses. Gives a number of insights about human nature, twentieth century living conditions and creativity. Based on the book by Frances Hudson.

results.title: House: after five years of living
results.brief_description: The first of a certain thread of films by Charles and Ray Eames that used still images in a very filmic way. The still camera offered a freedom and flexibility that allowed Charles and Ray to capture lyrical images of their house, its garden and its decor and to provide a lasting impression of the house during their life there. The house is a classic of post-war American architecture which the Eameses designed and built in 1949 as part of the Case Study House Program. Music composed by Elmer Bernstein. Performed by Martin Ruderman (flute), Dorothy Remsen (harp), Armand Kaproff (cello) and Elmer Bernstein (piano).
